> --- Tobias wrote:
>> [...] By using Javassist together with JUnit I managed to
>> add a powerful yet simple way of doing declarative (from
>> the test-class) mocking of troublesome classes [...]

--- Neil Swingler <neil@s...> wrote:
> I was working on something similar, extending JUnit. The big
> problem is how to insert the custom classloader early enough
> in each test run.

I did this (in JUnit 3) by overloading the TestCase.runBare method:  
When called, it reloaded itself (another instance of the same 
TestCase child class) through the "AOP" ClassLoader.  Then call the 
test methods.  You have to rely on reflection to make these calls, 
as the types aren't compatible across class loaders.  And I used a 
different constructor signature (and/or special flag set method) to 
let the test class loaded under the test ClassLoader know that it's 
the copy -- so it doesn't try to recursively load and call itself 
forever.

It costs a few seconds, per run, to go through another class 
loader.  But otherwise, it can work really well.
